The photo carboxylation of the benzylic C(sp3 )-H bond catalyzed by xanthone/nickel were examined by density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) calculations. This study corroborates the previous proposal that light promotes the H-transfer from benzylic C(sp3 )-H bond of the p-methoxytoluene to excited state of photocatalyst xanthone. Meanwhile, Ni(0) catalyst could mediate the H-transfer to occur via an electron-coupled-proton transfer manner, and then remarkably facilitates the carboxylation step (compared to the Ni-absent systems). After that, the generated Ni(I) intermediate and ketyl radical anion complete the carboxylation and electron transfer processes independently. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords DFT calculation Hydrogen atom transfer Photo carboxylation Ni catalysis Introduction As a nontoxic, cheap, and renewable C1 source, CO2 has recently attracted extensive research interest in organic synthesis. The carboxylation of organic compounds with CO2 has been successfully developed in the past decades [1–9], whereas the substrates are mainly limited to C(sp/sp2 )-H bonds [10–17]. Due to the low reactivity of C(sp3 )-H bonds and the instability of C(sp3 )-M (transition metal) complexes (formed by the hydrogen atom transfer processes) [18–25], the carboxylation of C(sp3 )-H bonds has been a long challenging issue. In recent years, the dual-catalytic systems with both photoredox and transition metal catalysts have made great progress, and a variety of valuable organic compounds has been prepared under mild conditions and with high efficiency [26–35]. Among them, the combination of photoredox and nickel catalyst represents an attractive system, predominantly due to the variety of the oxidation state of the nickel catalyst during reaction processes (e.g. Ni(0), Ni(I), Ni(II) and Ni(III)) [36–39]. In this senario, the excited photocatalyst could possibly generate different types of radicals via a single electron transfer process to the C-H substrate. Afterwards, the coordination of the radical to the nickel catalyst could stimulate the subsequent oxidation addition or migration insertion process. To this end, different types of C-C coupling (such as carboxylation [18–21], arylation [40,41] and alkylation [42,43]) could be accomplished. In this context, the introduction of photocatalysis, and especially via the photoredox cycles, has make it possible to conduct the carboxylation of C(sp3 )-H bond under mild conditions [21]. In 2015, Murakami and co-workers reported the direct carboxylation of benzylic C(sp3 )-H using the photosensitive o-alkylphenyl ketones as substrates, which could be excited simply upon irradiation with UV light or even solar light (Scheme 1 a) [18]. Inspired by the photoexcitation of ketones, they further disclosed the carboxylation of an allylic C-H bond of simple alkenes catalyzed by a xanthone and a copper complex under UV-light irradiation (Scheme 1b) [19]. In 2017, Jamison group developed the synthesis of α-amino acids through the photoredox of CO2 and amines in continuous flow (Scheme 1c) [20]. In all these reactions, light was suggested to be requisite to generate alkyl radicals [18,44–48,]. Recently, Murakami group has developed the direct photo carboxylation (λmax = 365 nm) of C(sp3 )-H bonds of a series of benzylic and aliphatic substrates at room temperature, in the presence of xanthone and Ni-catalyst (Scheme 1d) [49]. The mechanism of the reaction (in Scheme 1d) was suggested to start with the light excitation of xanthone (Scheme 2 ). Thereafter, hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) from the benzylic C(sp3 )-H bond to the carbonyl oxygen of the excited xanthone occurs to generate the ketyl and benzyl radicals. Then the benzyl radical combines with the nickel catalyst to form benzylnickel(I) species, from which carboxylation occurs via the insertion of carbon dioxide into the C-Ni(I) bond. Meanwhile, the ketyl radical undergoes a proton transfer to the base to form the ketyl radical anion. Finally, the single electron transfer from ketyl radical anion to benzylnickel(I) species regenerate the Ni(0) catalyst and the photocatalyst, and releases the carboxylate anion product simultaneously. Motivated by the robustness of the reaction in Scheme 1d and the high activity in aliphatic alkanes, we sought to explore the mechanism in detail with the aid of density functional theory calculations. The aim of this study is to elucidate several mechanistic issues: the pivotal influence of the photocatalyst, especially in the activation of the substrates; the possibility for a Ni-mediated C(sp3 )-H bond activation; the activation mode of CO2 in carboxylation process, and details for the electron flow along with the overall catalytic cycle. Computational details All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with Gaussian 16 program (Revision C.01) [50]. Geometry optimizations were carried out by B3LYP-D3BJ/def2-SVPP method [51–56]. The vibrational frequency was calculated at the same level of theory to identify each optimized stationary point as a local minimum or a transition state, and to evaluate the zero-point vibrational energy (ZPVE) and thermal corrections at 298 K. Based on the gas-phase optimized structures, the solution phase single-point energies (solvent=benzene, used in Murakami's experiment [49]) with SMD model [57] were calculated with M06 functional [56,58] and def2-TZVP basis set [59–61] for all atoms. Transition states were located using the Berny algorithm. Intrinsic reaction coordinates (IRC) [62,63] were calculated for each transition state to verify its connection with the two relevant minima. The 3D diagrams of computed species were generated by CYLView [64]. The time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) excited states calculations were performed at TD-B3LYP-D3BJ/def2-SVPP and TD-M06/def2-TZVP(SMD: benzene) for the geometry optimization and single-point energy calculations respectively. Results and discussion We first examined the benzylic C-H bond cleavage of p-methoxytoluene (sub) catalyzed by the ground state of xanthone and Ni catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1 , the approaching of sub to the photo-catalyst xanthone forms the complex S0-INT1 (S denotes singlet, and INT is short for intermediate), whose energy is 4.7 kcal/mol higher than the precursor. Thereafter, the energy barrier of the six-membered ring H-transfer step is as high as 63.4 kcal/mol, which is inaccessible under the experimental conditions (at room temperature [49]). Meanwhile, the transition metal catalyst (cat-2) involved C-H bond cleavage might start with the coordination of xanthone or sub with the nickel center. In view of the 2:1 ratio of the di(2-pyridyl)methane (L) and the Ni(0) catalyst (e.g. Ni(cod)2) in Murakami's study, we used NiL2 (i.e. cat-2) as the initial state of the Ni-catalyst. Removing one L from cat-2 is endergonic by 18.6 kcal/mol. By contrast, the formation of the tertiary intermediate between cat-2, xanthone, and sub is endergonic by 10.9 kcal/mol, and the subsequent dissociation of one L from cat-2 moiety could then generates a significantly more stable intermediate of S0-INT3. Herein, the calculation results indicate that the coordination of the benzene ring of xanthone to cat-2 is more favorable than that of the substrate (Fig. S1). The formation of the intermediate S0-INT3 from cat-2 and S0-INT1 is exothermic by 9.8 kcal/mol. Then the hydrogen atom transfer from the benzylic C-H bond to xanthone occurs via a Ni-assisted five-membered ring transition state S0-TS2, with an activation free energy barrier of 44.2 kcal/mol, which is still too high to overcome at room temperature. According to these results, the benzylic C-H bond cleavage is unlikely to be mediated by the ground state catalysts. As the photoexcitation of xanthones to its long-lived triplet state have been well elucidated in recent studies [65], we mainly focus on the H-transfer from the substrate to the T1 state of the photo catalyst (formed by an intersystem crossing (ISC) from the S1 state, Fig. 2 [46,66]). Of note, the detailed transformations from the singlet excited state species were also examined for clarity reasons. In view of the high energy demands, the details were given in Fig. S2. According to the calculation results, the vertical excitation of xanthone is relatively more energy-demanding than that of the binary system of S0-INT1 (Fig. S2) [67], there is π–π Stacking interaction between the substrate and xanthone. This π–π Stacking interaction could redshift the ultraviolet absorption wavelength in the system, thereby reducing the vertical excitation energy of the system [68–70]. And therefore we mainly focus on the ISC of the S1 state of S0-INT1 to its T1 excited state. Following the recent study by Coote and co-workers [71], the ISC could occur via S1→T2→T1 transformation. After that, the benzylic C-H bond cleavage to the T1 state of T1-INT1 need to overcome the energy barrier of only 2.3 kcal/mol to generate ketyl and benzyl radicals. Nevertheless, the subsequent approaching of CO2 to the benzyl radical (T1-INT2→T1-INT3→T1-INT4) is highly endergonic by 43.3 kcal/mol, indicating the difficulty of the direct carboxylation step (without the participation of cat-2). For comparison, the coordination of the triplet intermediate T1-INT1 with cat-2 could possibly generate T1-INT2, and this process is highly exergonic by 54.3 kcal/mol. Thereafter, the benzylic C-H bond cleavage occurs via the transition state T1-TS2, in which the benzylic hydrogen transfer occurs with a spontaneous coordination of substrate to the Ni center of cat-2. The energy barrier of this process is 20.0 kcal/mol, and T1-INT6 is then formed. After that, the transferred H atom on the photocatalyst could be removed by t-BuO− in the reaction system [72,73], releasing the radical anion xanthone-RA (RA denotes radical anion) as a result. This process (T1-INT6→S0-INT4) is exergonic by 46.8 kcal/mol. Comparing the aforementioned two pathways from T1-INT1, we note that the hydrogen transfer directly on T1-INT1 occurs with a very low energy barrier of only 2.3 kcal/mol, while the coordination to Ni-catalyst occurs via a barrier-less pathway. Due to significantly higher concentration of the substrate than that of the Ni-catalyst [49], we suggest that the two pathways could be competitive. Specifically, the two pathways could converge at the intermediate T1-INT6 (Fig. 2). NBO charge and Mulliken spin density analysis was then used to elucidate the details for the benzylic C-H bond cleavage from T1-INT1 to T1-INT2. As shown in Fig. 3 , the charge distribution in T1-INT1 indicates the electron transfer from the substrate (and mainly the benzylic hydrogen atom) to the excited photocatalyst. With the gradual formation of H-O bond, the spin density on xanthone decreases, while the charge (0.01e) and the spin density (ρ = 0.98) of the sub part indicate the benzylic radical characteristics of T1-INT2. Therefore, the C-H bond dissociation formally correspond to a HAT pathway. Compared to Ni-absent system, electron flow occurs mainly from the Ni catalyst to xanthone in the Ni-presence system. First, the spin density of 1.06 on the Ni catalyst moiety in T1-INT5, and especially the spin density on Ni center (ρ=1.00) demonstrates a formal Ni(I) therein. Meanwhile, the charge (-0.84) and spin density (0.93) distributed on the xanthone moiety indicates a formal radical anionic characteristic of the photo catalyst. In other words, a single electron transfer from the Ni catalyst to the photocatalyst xanthone occurs during the formation of T1-INT5, providing its extra-stability (compared to the precursor of T1-INT1). The subsequent benzylic C-H bond cleavage from T1-INT5 formally corresponds to a proton transfer process, due to the significantly reduced electron density on the {[Ni]+sub} groups, but the maintained spin density therein. Throughout the Ni-mediated C-H dissociation step, the hydrogen atom transfer occurs in a manner of electron-coupled proton transfer process, similar to the recent study on the H-transfer step of the photoredox-cobalt co-catalysis system [74]. To verify the details of the benzylic C-H bond cleavage process, we also examined the charge evolutions from the internal reaction coordinates (IRC) of the two transition states T1-TS1 and T1-TS2, as shown in Fig. 4 a. The abscissa is the distance which is the projection of IRC between the O atom (in the xanthone carbonyl group) and the H atom (in the substrate benzyl group), and the ordinate is the total charge of each part in the transition state. In the absence of the Ni catalyst, the charge of the xanthone moiety decreases continuously until the formation of T1-TS1, from which the charge on the sub segment quickly changed to ∼0, while the sum of charge on the H atom and the xanthone fragments become close to zero. Therefore, the IRC curve of T1-TS1 is consistent with a formal HAT mechanism, generating free radicals as a result. In the presence of Ni catalyst, the photo catalyst xanthone is negatively charged in the initial state, and the nickel catalyst [Ni] is positively charged. Along the reaction path, and especially nearby the transition state, xanthone and H fragments act as the electron donor, while the sub and [Ni] fragments act as the electron acceptor. The results correlate with an electron-flow process shown in Fig. 4b: single electron transfer fist occurs to generate a cationic [Ni] and an anionic xanthone in the initial state, and then nucleophilic attack of the negatively charged xanthone to the benzylic hydrogen on substrate occurs, with a simultaneous electron transfer from the dissociating C-H bond to the Ni catalyst. After the H-transfer transition state T1-TS2, the total charge on both {[Ni]+[sub]} and {xanthone+H} fragments are close to 0, demonstrating the neutral charged state of both parts. Due to the weak interaction between these two parts, T1-INT6 in Fig. 4b can be viewed as a pair of free radicals, i.e. Ni(I) radical and ketyl radical. In view of the thermodynamic and kinetic facilities of the carboxylation on Ni(I) intermediate reported in recent studies [75–77], we examined the direct carboxylation on the structure of [Ni]-[sub] (S0-INT4, vide infra). Meanwhile, the ketyl radical can possibly react with the base t-BuOK (in the reaction system [49]) to generate the ketyl radical anion through proton transfer process [24], and this step is exergonic by 37.2 kcal/mol (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. 5 , the carboxylation of S0-INT4 starts with the coordination of CO2 to the NiI centre via an ƞ2-coordination of the C=O double bond. Then the formed S0-INT5 undergoes the carboxylation elementary step via the transition state S0-TS3, with a free energy barrier of only 5.3 kcal/mol, which is remarkably more feasible than the Ni-absence pathway (Fig. 2). The relative energy of the intermediate S0-INT6 is lower than the precursor of S0-INT5 by 17.0 kcal/mol. After that, the ketyl radical anion xanthone-RA acts as an electron donor to promote the release of the carboxylate product, and the regeneration of the photocatalyst xanthone, and Ni catalyst cat-2. The distortion/interaction analysis of the key transition states in substrate carboxylation process is shown in Figs. S5 and S6. In addition, we also explored the effect of different ligands ((2-Py)2CH2, bpy and tbbpy) in the Ni catalyst on the subsequent carboxylation process in Fig. S7. On the basis of the aforementioned results and discussions, the most feasible pathway for the photocarboxylation catalyzed by nickel and xanthone was deduced. The reaction starts with an interaction of substrate p-methoxytoluene with the photo catalyst xanthone to form a binary complex S0-INT1, from which photo-excitation and intersystem crossing occur successively to generate the T1 state of T1-INT1. After that, H transfer could occur via two competitive pathways, in the presence or absence of Ni-catalyst. In absence of Ni-catalyst, H-transfer occurs via a typical HAT process. In the presence of Ni-catalyst, the complexation of the Ni catalyst with T1-INT1 results in a spontaneously electron transfer to the triplet xanthone, following with a proton transfer from the benzylic C(sp3 )-H bond of the substrate to xanthone and a simultaneous Ni-C bond formation. The two pathways could converge at the intermediate T1-INT6, the NiI part and the ketone radical of which then undergo independent carboxylation and proton transfer steps, respectively. Carboxylation occurs in an inner-sphere pathway, starting with the coordination of CO2 to nickel center of S0-INT4 in an ƞ2-mode. The final electron transfer from xanthone-RA to S0-INT6 enables the release of the carboxylate product and the regeneration of the photo and transition catalysts. Conclusion In summary, the mechanism of the photo carboxylation of benzylic C-H bond of p-methoxytoluene (with CO2) mediated by xanthone and Ni(0) catalyst were examined by DFT calculations. The overall catalytic cycle occurs via a successive hydrogen atom transfer and carboxylation steps. The HAT is facile no matter Ni(0) catalyst is present or not, while the carboxylation step could be significantly promoted by the Ni-catalyst. Without the Ni(0) catalyst, the hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) occurs easily in a traditional HAT mode, while the addition of Ni catalyst induces hydrogen atom transfer process to occur electron-coupled-proton transfer pattern. The present study sheds light on the detailed functions of the photo-catalyst and transition-metal catalyst in the carboxylation reactions, and the interactions might be possibly generalized to other photoredox systems with co-catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The photo carboxylation of the benzylic C(sp3 )-H bond catalyzed by xanthone/nickel were examined by density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) calculations. This study corroborates the previous proposal that light promotes the H-transfer from benzylic C(sp3 )-H bond of the p-methoxytoluene to excited state of photocatalyst xanthone. Meanwhile, Ni(0) catalyst could mediate the H-transfer to occur via an electron-coupled-proton transfer manner, and then remarkably facilitates the carboxylation step (compared to the Ni-absent systems). After that, the generated Ni(I) intermediate and ketyl radical anion complete the carboxylation and electron transfer processes independently.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic study on the photo carboxylation of benzylic C-H bonds by xanthone and Ni(0) catalysts
